text: \f + \fr 41:1 \ft \xt Job 41:1–34 \ft in the English Bible is 40:25–41:26 in the Hebrew Bible \f* “Can you draw out Leviathan with a fishhook?
Or\f + \fr 41:1 \ft Hebrew “And” \f* ⸤can you tie down its mouth with a cord⸥?\f + \fr 41:1 \ft Literally “with a cord can you press down its tongue” \f*
Can you put a rope in its nose?
Or\f + \fr 41:2 \ft Hebrew “And” \f* can you pierce its jawbone with a hook?
Will it make numerous pleas for mercy to you?
Or will it speak gentle words to you?
Will it make a covenant with you?
Will you take it as a slave forever?
Will you play with it as \add with\add* birds
and put it on a leash for your girls?
Will guildsmen bargain over it?
Will they divide it between tradesmen?
Can you fill its kin with harpoons
or\f + \fr 41:7 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* its head with fish spears?
Lay your hands on it;
think about \add the\add* battle—you will not do \add it\add* again!
“Look, ⸤the hope of capturing it⸥\f + \fr 41:9 \ft Literally “its hope” \f* is false.
Will one be hurled down even at its sight?
\add Is\add* it not fierce when somebody stirs it?
Who \add then\add* \add is\add* he \add who\add* would stand ⸤before it⸥?\f + \fr 41:10 \ft Or “Who \fq is \ft he \fq then \ft \fq who \ft could stand before me?”; literally “to the face of me” \f*
Who has come to confront me, that\f + \fr 41:11 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* I should repay \add him\add*?
Under all the heavens, ⸤it belongs to me⸥.\f + \fr 41:11 \ft Literally “to me” \f*
“I will not keep quiet \add concerning\add* its limbs
or\f + \fr 41:12 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* concerning \add the\add* extent of its might and \add the\add* gracefulness of its frame.
Who can strip off ⸤its outer covering⸥?\f + \fr 41:13 \ft Literally “\fq the \ft surface of its garment” \f*
Who can penetrate its double harness?
Who can open \add the\add* doors of its face?
Its teeth all around \add are\add* fearsome.
Its back\f + \fr 41:15 \ft LXX; or “pride” \f* \add has\add* scales of shields;
it is shut up closely \add as with\add* a seal.
They are close ⸤to one another⸥—\f + \fr 41:16 \ft Literally “one to one” \f*
even\f + \fr 41:16 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* \add the\add* air cannot come between them.
They are joined ⸤one to another⸥;\f + \fr 41:17 \ft Literally “a man to his brother” \f*
they cling together and cannot be separated.
“Its snorting flashes forth light,
and its eyes \add are\add* ⸤red like dawn⸥.\f + \fr 41:18 \ft Literally “like eyelids of dawn” \f*
Torches go from its mouth;
sparks of fire shoot out.
Smoke comes from its nostrils
as \add from\add* a kettle boiling and \add burning\add* bulrushes.
Its breath kindles charcoal,
and a flame comes from its mouth.
“Strength abides in its neck,
and dismay\f + \fr 41:22 \ft Or “strength” \f* dances ⸤before it⸥.\f + \fr 41:22 \ft Literally “to the face of him/it” \f*
Its flesh’s folds of skin cling together;
it is cast on it—it will not be moved.
Its heart is cast as stone;
yes,\f + \fr 41:24 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* it is cast as \add the\add* lower millstone.
⸤When it raises itself⸥,\f + \fr 41:25 \ft Literally “From his/its rising up” \f* \add the\add* mighty ones are terrified;
they retreat because of its thrashing.
Reaching it \add with the\add* sword does not avail,
\add nor\add* \add with the\add* spear, \add the\add* dart, or\f + \fr 41:26 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* \add the\add* javelin.
It regards iron as straw,
bronze as rotten wood.
⸤An arrow⸥\f + \fr 41:28 \ft Literally “A son of a bow” \f* will not make it flee;
sling stones are turned to stubble for it.
Clubs are regarded as stubble,
and it laughs at \add the\add* short sword’s rattle.
“Its underparts \add are\add* shards of a potsherd;
it moves over mud \add like\add* a threshing sledge.
It makes \add the\add* deep boil like a cooking pot;
it makes \add the\add* sea like a pot of ointment.
Behind it, ⸤it leaves a glistening wake⸥;\f + \fr 41:32 \ft Literally “it lights up \fq the \ft path” \f*
one would think \add that\add* the deep \add has\add* gray hair.
“⸤On the ground it has no equal⸥\f + \fr 41:33 \ft Literally “There is not on \fq the \ft ground its likeness” \f*—
a\f + \fr 41:33 \ft Hebrew “the” \f* creature without fear.
It observes all \add the\add* lofty;
it \add is\add* king ⸤over all that are proud⸥.”\f + \fr 41:34 \ft Literally “over all sons of pride” \f*
